trustfund:
TF020945-PHRD-PRIVATE SECTOR DEV. PROJECT,TF023083-PHRD-SUBIC BAY FREEPORT,TF020930-NEW ZEALAND CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF020290-IRISH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF035747-PHILIPPINES - SECOND SUBIC BAY
            FREEPORT PROJECT,TF035634-PHILIPPINES - SECOND SUBIC BAY
            FREEPORT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project is satisfactory,
            and sustainability is likely, in spite of the
            Government's unsatisfactory performance during
            implementation, when due to civil unrest, and court
            challenges, a number of actions by the Government,
            diminished the integrity of the Subic Bay Metropolitan
            Authority's (SBMA) policy framework, thus introducing a
            certain ambiguity into the free-port investment environment.
            The lessons convey that, regardless of the adequacy of
            technical assistance programs, for the conversion of
            existing infrastructure into a free-port operation -
            valuable from a strategic conversion point of view - future
            operations should nonetheless, focus on the institutional
            strengthening of the free-port authority, to be able to
            operate within well defined regulations. This planning,
            should clearly establish the role of the private sector,
            without undermining the Administration's, and the
            country's revenues, and benefits, aiming instead at
            distinct, and mutually complementary roles. To this end, a
            strong legal framework is required, not only to build
            institutional capacity, but to enhance the operating
            autonomy, and flexibility of a government-owned and
            controlled corporation, and prevent the limitations
            encountered by the SBMA's charter, and dual status.
            Project changes should be rationally evaluated, and the
            inclusion of a strong social development components,
            significantly enhances private sector development.
